vocabulary.english: to have a discussion about something (RFF)
to scoop something to give to something/someone (DF(DO))
to cook something to give to someone (DF(DO))

contents.markdown: _Pag-...-an_ verbs are second tier verbs that I included because some can be used to form RFF and LF sentences – two focuses that you have not encountered up to this point.
<u>Traits of Pag-...-an Verbs</u>
Used to form DF(D), DF(DO), LF, OF(O) or RFF sentences. LF and RFF have no symbols in parentheses after them because they can go with any variant.
<u>Infinitive</u>

Add _pag_ before the root, like you did for _mag_- verbs. As with _mag_- verbs, insert the “–” if the root starts with a vowel. Add _an_ after the root, like you did for -_an_ verbs. Sometimes there is morphing, but all aspects are derived from the infinitive, so memorizing the infinitive is enough.
Ex: usap => pag-usapan
Ex: aral => pag-aralan
Ex: luto => paglutuan
Ex: tawa => pagtawanán
Ex: sandok => pagsandukán
<u>Completed Aspect</u>
Take the infinitive and change the _pag_ into _pinag_. The rules for stress, for all aspects, are the same as for _mag_- verbs.
<u>Uncompleted Aspect</u>
Take the infinitive, change the _pag_ into _pinag_ and repeat the first syllable of the root.
<u>Contemplated Aspect</u>
Take the infinitive and duplicate the first syllable of the root.
<u>Referential Focus (RFF)</u>

RFF verbs all have something to do with communication, and add the nuance of “about” something. They correspond to _mag_- verbs, and take the same complements. But the _mag_- verbs have to use _tungkol sa_ to express the “about” nuance.
Ex: pag-usapan = to have a discussion about something, RFF
Ex: mag-usap = to discus, AF(O)
An RFF verb takes the same complements as its corresponding _mag_- verb. Referential Focus is pretty rare; it is only formed with a few _pag-...-an_ verbs, and no other affixes.
<u>Locative Focus (LF)</u>

\*\*LF verbs focus on the location\*\* in which an action occurs. They correspond to -_um_- or _mag_- verbs, and take the same complements. They have similarities to, and are sometimes confused with DF verbs. But unlike LF verbs, **DF verbs may focus on a direction/destination/goal** of an action. To show the grammatical difference, here is a comparison of double-object (DO) sentences in both focuses.
Ex: lutuan = to cook something to give to someone (DF)

item.tagalog: Nilutuan niya sila ng adobo sa kawali.
item.english: She cooked adobo for them in the pan. (DF)

contents.markdown: Ex: paglutuan = to cook something somewhere (LF)

item.tagalog: Pinaglutuan niya ng adobo ang kawali para sa kanila.
item.english: She cooked adobo for them in the pan. (LF)

contents.markdown: An LF verb takes the same complements as its corresponding _mag_- verb. Locative Focus is also quite rare; it is only formed with three different affixes, of which _pag-...-an_ verbs are the most common.

exampleSentences.english: They are both hard to talk about.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pag-aaralan ni Joshua ang pinakanakakatuwa nang mga alas singko.
exampleSentences.english: Joshua will study the funnest one around five o'clock.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Huwag mong pagtawanan ang sarili mo nang ganun.
exampleSentences.english: Do not laugh at yourself like that.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Paglulutuan ba ni Jasmine ng manok ang kawali para sa kanila, parang nanay nila?
exampleSentences.english: Will Jasmine cook adobo for them in the pan, like their mother?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pagsandukan po ninyo ng adobo ang nakatira sa lugar ni Analyn.
exampleSentences.english: Scoop some adobo for the one living at Analyn's place. (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pinag-usapan namin ang lalaking may sobrang bilis na sasakyan.
exampleSentences.english: We discussed the man who has the very fast car.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kasing hirap nito ang mga pinag-aaralan mo, di ba?
exampleSentences.english: The ones you are studying are just as difficult as this, right?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Mas gusto ni David na pagtawanan si Maria kaysa kay Angel.
exampleSentences.english: David likes to mock Maria more than Angel.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pinaglutuan niya ng manok ang kawali nang ganito.
exampleSentences.english: He cooked chicken in the pan like this.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Magkakaaso si Joe, kaya pinagsandukan ko siya ng tubig.
exampleSentences.english: Joe will have a dog, so I scooped him some water. (magka-)
